bioghist.p: Henry Holiday (1839-1927) was an English Pre-Raphaelite painter, stained-glass artist, and illustrator. His most famous painting was Dante and Beatrice. In 1916, Holiday met Ada Forestier-Walker, who personified for him Dante's Beatrice. His illustrations were also well regarded. A set of his illustrations were used for a 1981 edition of Lewis Carroll's Hunting of the Snark, published by William Kaufmann in cooperation with Bryn Mawr College.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of letters from Henry Holiday to Ada Forestier-Walker, whose portrait he wished to paint, as well as a 1918 sketch of "Beatrice." Also included are plates and photographs of illustrations used in the William Kaufmann edition of Hunting of the Snark.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
